name: First Generation
description: The first generation of wireless telephone technology, which was analog in nature and had limited coverage and capacity.

name: Second Generation
description: A standard for mobile telecommunications, superseding the original analog cellular networks (1G) and preceding 3G. It introduced digital encryption of conversations and data services, such as SMS and MMS.

name: Third Generation
description: A standard for mobile telecommunications, superseding 2G and preceding 4G. It brought greater network capacity and internet services to mobile devices, enabling video calling and mobile broadband.

name: Fourth Generation
description: A standard for mobile telecommunications, superseding 3G and preceding 5G.

name: Fifth Generation
description: The fifth generation of mobile network technology, offering faster speeds and more reliable connections on smartphones and other devices.

name: Air Conditioning
description: A system for controlling the humidity, ventilation, and temperature in a building.

name: Anno Domini
description: Latin phrase meaning 'In the year of our Lord', used in the Gregorian calendar to reference the years since the birth of Jesus Christ.

name: Americans with Disabilities Act
description: US law that prohibits discrimination against individuals with disabilities in all areas of public life.

name: Artificial Intelligence
description: The simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, especially computer systems.

name: Active-Matrix Organic Light-Emitting Diode
description: A type of OLED display device technology which is used in smartphones, tablets, and televisions.

name: Associated Press
description: A multinational non-profit news agency headquartered in New York City. The AP is owned by its contributing newspapers, radio, and television stations in the United States, all of which contribute stories to the AP and use material written by its staff journalists.

name: Application Programming Interface
description: A set of rules and protocols for building and interacting with software applications.

name: Augmented Reality
description: An interactive experience of a real-world environment where objects in the real world are enhanced by computer-generated perceptual information.

name: As Soon As Possible
description: An abbreviation used to indicate that something should be done immediately.

name: Association of Southeast Asian Nations
description: A regional intergovernmental organization comprising ten countries in Southeast Asia.

name: Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives
description: A federal law enforcement organization within the United States Department of Justice.

name: Business to Business
description: A type of transaction that exists between businesses, such as one involving a manufacturer and wholesaler, or a wholesaler and a retailer.

name: Business to Consumer
description: Business or transactions conducted directly between a company and consumers who are the end-users of its products or services.

name: Before Christ
description: A time designation used to indicate years before the estimated birth of Jesus in the Gregorian calendar.

name: Before Common Era
description: A secular alternative to the traditional BC (Before Christ).

name: Brazil, Russia, India, China, South Africa
description: An acronym for an association of five major emerging national economies.

name: Capital Expenditure
description: Funds used by a company to acquire or upgrade physical assets such as property, buildings, an industrial plant, technology, or equipment.

name: Customs and Border Protection
description: The largest federal law enforcement agency of the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, charged with regulating and facilitating international trade, collecting import duties, and enforcing U.S. regulations.

name: California Consumer Privacy Act
description: A state statute intended to enhance privacy rights and consumer protection for residents of California, United States.

name: Code Division Multiple Access
description: A channel access method used by various radio communication technologies. It should not be confused with the mobile phone standards called cdmaOne, CDMA2000 (the 3G evolution of cdmaOne) and WCDMA (the 3G standard used by GSM carriers), which are often referred to as simply CDMA, and use CDMA as an underlying channel access method.

name: Chief Data Officer
description: A corporate officer responsible for enterprise-wide governance and utilization of information as an asset.

name: Common Era
description: A term used in the Julian and Gregorian calendars to refer to the current era, an alternative to the use of AD (Anno Domini).

name: Chief Executive Officer
description: The highest-ranking executive in a company, whose primary responsibilities include making major corporate decisions and managing the overall operations and resources of a company.

name: Central Intelligence Agency
description: A civilian foreign intelligence service of the federal government of the United States, tasked with gathering, processing, and analyzing national security information from around the world.

name: Chief Information Officer
description: An executive who oversees the information technology (IT) needs of a company including its data, related technologies, and support services.

name: Chief Information Security Officer
description: A senior-level executive responsible for developing and implementing an information security program, which includes procedures and policies designed to protect enterprise communications, systems and assets from both internal and external threats.

name: Chief Marketing Officer
description: An executive who is in charge of developing and overseeing marketing and advertising plans of a business.

name: Chief Operating Officer
description: A senior executive tasked with overseeing the day-to-day administrative and operational functions of a business.

name: Cost Per Click
description: A method of billing advertising space or marketing campaigns where the advertiser pays each time a user clicks on their ad.

name: Central Processing Unit
description: The primary component of a computer that performs most of the processing inside the computer.

name: Customer Relationship Management
description: A strategy for managing an organization's relationships and interactions with customers and potential customers.

name: Cascading Style Sheets
description: A style sheet language used for describing the look and formatting of a document written in HTML or XML.

name: Comma-Separated Values
description: A simple file format used to store tabular data, such as a spreadsheet or database.

name: Call to Action
description: An instruction to the audience designed to provoke an immediate response, usually using an imperative verb such as 'call now', 'find out more' or 'visit a store today'.

name: Chief Technology Officer
description: An executive who is responsible for the management of an organization's research and development (R&D) and technological needs.

name: Click Through Rate
description: The ratio of users who click on a specific link to the number of total users who view a page, email, or advertisement.

name: District of Columbia
description: The capital of the United States. It is not a state and is under the direct jurisdiction of the federal government.

name: Drug Enforcement Administration
description: A United States federal law enforcement agency under the Department of Justice, tasked with combating drug trafficking and distribution within the U.S.

name: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol
description: A network management protocol used on Internet Protocol networks for automatically assigning IP addresses and other communication parameters to devices connected to the network.

name: Dalsey, Hillblom and Lynn
description: An international courier, parcel, and express mail service, which is a division of the German logistics company Deutsche Post DHL.

name: Department of Homeland Security
description: A cabinet department of the U.S. federal government with responsibilities in public security, roughly comparable to the interior or home ministries of other countries.

name: Do It Yourself
description: A method of building, modifying, or repairing things without the direct aid of experts or professionals.

name: Deep Learning
description: A subset of machine learning in artificial intelligence (AI) that has networks capable of learning unsupervised from data that is unstructured or unlabeled.

name: Deoxyribonucleic Acid
description: A molecule composed of two chains that coil around each other to form a double helix carrying genetic instructions for the development, functioning, growth and reproduction of all known organisms and many viruses.

name: Domain Name System
description: A hierarchical and decentralized naming system for computers, services, or other resources connected to the Internet or a private network.

name: Department of Defense
description: An executive branch department of the federal government of the United States charged with coordinating and supervising all agencies and functions of the government directly related to national security and the United States Armed Forces.

name: Department of Justice
description: A federal executive department of the U.S. government, responsible for the enforcement of the law and administration of justice in the United States.

name: Exempli Gratia
description: A Latin phrase that means 'for example'. It is used to introduce one or more examples of something mentioned previously in the sentence and/or context.

name: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization
description: A measure of a company's operating performance. Essentially, it's a way to evaluate a company's performance without having to factor in financing decisions, accounting decisions or tax environments.

name: European Economic Area
description: An international agreement which enables the extension of the European Union's single market to non-EU member parties. The EEA links the EU member states and three EFTA states (Iceland, Liechtenstein, and Norway) into an internal market governed by the same basic rules.

name: Exclusive OR
description: A logical operation that outputs true only when inputs differ (one is true, the other is false). It is symbolized by the prefix operator J and by the infix operators XOR, EOR, EXOR, ⊻, ⩒, ⩛, ⊕, ↮, and ≢.

name: Environmental Protection Agency
description: An independent executive agency of the United States federal government tasked with environmental protection matters.

name: Earnings Per Share
description: The portion of a company's profit allocated to each outstanding share of common stock. It serves as an indicator of a company's profitability.

name: Electromagnetic Radiation Emitting Devices
description: A category of devices that emit electromagnetic radiation, which can include everything from microwave ovens to cell phones to computer monitors. These devices are regulated for safety by various agencies worldwide.

name: Enterprise Resource Planning
description: A type of software that organizations use to manage day-to-day business activities such as accounting, procurement, project management, risk management and compliance, and supply chain operations.

name: Estimated Time of Arrival
description: The time when a ship, vehicle, aircraft, cargo, emergency service or computer file is expected to arrive at a certain place.

name: Et Cetera
description: A Latin phrase that means 'and other similar things', or 'and so forth'.

name: European Telecommunications Standards Institute
description: An independent, non-profit, standardization organization in the telecommunications industry in Europe, headquartered in Sophia-Antipolis, France. ETSI produces globally-applicable standards for Information and Communications Technologies (ICT), including fixed, mobile, radio, converged, broadcast and internet technologies.

name: European Union
description: A political and economic union of 27 member states that are located primarily in Europe. It has an area of 4,233,255.3 km? and an estimated total population of about 447 million.

name: Exclusive OR
description: A logical operation that outputs true only when inputs differ (one is true, the other is false). It is symbolized by the prefix operator J and by the infix operators XOR, EOR, EXOR, ⊻, ⩒, ⩛, ⊕, ↮, and ≢.

name: Frequently Asked Questions
description: A list of questions and answers, all supposed to be commonly asked in some context, and pertaining to a particular topic. The format is commonly used on email mailing lists and other online forums, where certain common questions tend to recur.

name: Federal Bureau of Investigation
description: The domestic intelligence and security service of the United States and its principal federal law enforcement agency. Operating under the jurisdiction of the United States Department of Justice, the FBI is also a member of the U.S. Intelligence Community and reports to both the Attorney General and the Director of National Intelligence.

name: Federal Communications Commission
description: An independent agency of the United States government that regulates communications by radio, television, wire, satellite, and cable across the United States.

name: Food and Drug Administration
description: A federal agency of the Department of Health and Human Services. The FDA is responsible for protecting and promoting public health through the control and supervision of food safety, tobacco products, dietary supplements, prescription and over-the-counter pharmaceutical drugs (medications), vaccines, biopharmaceuticals, blood transfusions, medical devices, electromagnetic radiation emitting devices (ERED), cosmetics, animal foods & feed and veterinary products.

name: Frequency Division Multiple Access
description: A channel access method used in multiple-access protocols as a channelization protocol. FDMA gives users an individual allocation of one or several frequency bands, allowing them to use the allocated radio spectrum without interfering with each other.

name: Federal Express
description: An American multinational delivery services company headquartered in Memphis, Tennessee.

name: Federal Trade Commission
description: An independent agency of the United States government whose main goals are the promotion of consumer protection and the elimination and prevention of anticompetitive business practices.

name: File Transfer Protocol
description: A standard network protocol used for the transfer of computer files between a client and server on a computer network.

name: For Your Information
description: A common abbreviation of For Your Information

name: Group of Twenty
description: An international forum for the governments and central bank governors from 19 countries and the European Union (EU).

name: Group of Seven
description: An intergovernmental organization consisting of Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States.

name: Google Analytics
description: A web analytics service offered by Google that tracks and reports website traffic.

name: General Data Protection Regulation
description: A regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union (EU) and the European Economic Area (EEA).

name: Graphics Interchange Format
description: A bitmap image format that was developed by a team at the online services provider CompuServe led by American computer scientist Steve Wilhite and released on 15 June 1987.

name: Graphics Processing Unit
description: A specialized electronic circuit designed to rapidly manipulate and alter memory to accelerate the creation of images in a frame buffer intended for output to a display device.

name: Global System for Mobile Communications
description: A standard developed by the European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) to describe the protocols for second-generation (2G) digital cellular networks used by mobile devices such as mobile phones and tablets. It became a global standard for mobile communications and was particularly dominant in Europe and Asia.

name: Graphical User Interface
description: A form of user interface that allows users to interact with electronic devices through graphical icons and audio indicator such as primary notation, instead of text-based user interfaces, typed command labels or text navigation.

name: Hard Disk Drive
description: A data storage device used for storing and retrieving digital information using rapidly rotating disks (platters) coated with magnetic material.

name: High-Definition Multimedia Interface
description: A proprietary audio/video interface for transmitting uncompressed video data and compressed or uncompressed digital audio data from an HDMI-compliant source device, such as a display controller, to a compatible computer monitor, video projector, digital television, or digital audio device.

name: Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act
description: A United States legislation that provides data privacy and security provisions for safeguarding medical information.

name: Home Location Register
description: A database used for storage and management of subscriptions. The central database for a mobile network, it is the equivalent of a subscriber database. It holds information about each mobile subscriber that belongs to the home GSM network.

name: Human Resources
description: The set of individuals who make up the workforce of an organization, business sector, industry, or economy.

name: Human Resource Management
description: The strategic approach to the effective management of people in a company or organization such that they help their business gain a competitive advantage.

name: Hypertext Markup Language
description: Hardcover Manual Text Layout

name: Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure
description: An extension of the Hypertext Transfer Protocol. It is used for secure communication over a computer network, and is widely used on the Internet.

name: Id Est
description: Latin phrase that means 'in other words'. It is used to clarify or simplify a statement.

name: Infrastructure as a Service
description: A form of cloud computing that provides virtualized computing resources over the internet.

name: International Criminal Court
description: An intergovernmental organization and international tribunal that sits in The Hague, Netherlands. It is the first and only permanent international court with jurisdiction to prosecute individuals for the international crimes of genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes, and the crime of aggression.

name: Immigration and Customs Enforcement
description: A federal law enforcement agency under the U.S. Department of Homeland Security, principally responsible for immigration enforcement, with additional responsibilities in countering transnational crime.

name: International Court of Justice
description: The principal judicial organ of the United Nations (UN). It settles legal disputes submitted by states and gives advisory opinions on legal issues referred by authorized U.N. organs and specialized agencies.

name: International Electrotechnical Commission
description: A non-profit, non-governmental international standards organization that prepares and publishes International Standards for all electrical, electronic and related technologies.

name: International Monetary Fund
description: An international financial institution headquartered in Washington, D.C., consisting of 190 countries working to foster global monetary cooperation, secure financial stability, facilitate international trade, promote high employment and sustainable economic growth, and reduce poverty around the world.

name: In My Humble Opinion
description: An internet slang expression used to preface a statement, opinion, or estimate wherein the speaker wishes to convey a sense of modesty, deference to the audience, or even self-effacement.

name: In My Opinion
description: An internet slang phrase used often in message board posts, on social networking sites, in texting, and in instant messaging, to preface a comment or an opinion as being the personal opinion of the poster.

name: International Mobile Subscriber Identity
description: A number that uniquely identifies every user of a cellular network. It is stored as a 64-bit field and is sent by the mobile device to the network. It is also used for acquiring other details of the mobile in the home location register (HLR) or as locally copied in the visitor location register (VLR). To prevent eavesdroppers from identifying and tracking the subscriber on the radio interface, the IMSI is sent as rarely as possible and a randomly-generated TMSI is sent instead.

name: Internet of Things
description: The network of physical objects?'things'?that are embedded with sensors, software, and other technologies for the purpose of connecting and exchanging data with other devices and systems over the internet.

name: In Other Words
description: A phrase used to introduce a more simple, different, or creative explanation or metaphor.

name: Intellectual Property
description: A category of property that includes intangible creations of the human intellect. It encompasses patents, copyrights, and trademarks, among other types.

name: Internet Protocol
description: The principal communications protocol in the Internet protocol suite for relaying datagrams across network boundaries.

name: Intellectual Property Rights
description: Legal rights granted with the aim to protect creations of the intellect. These rights include trademarks, copyright, patents, industrial design rights, and in some jurisdictions trade secrets.

name: Internal Revenue Service
description: The revenue service of the United States federal government responsible for collecting taxes and administering the Internal Revenue Code, the main body of federal statutory tax law.

name: International Organization for Standardization
description: An independent, non-governmental international organization with a membership of 165 national standards bodies. It develops and publishes international standards.

name: Information Technology
description: The use of computers to store, retrieve, transmit, and manipulate data or information. IT is typically used within the context of business operations as opposed to personal or entertainment technologies.

name: Joint Photographic Experts Group
description: A commonly used method of lossy compression for digital images, particularly for those images produced by digital photography.

name: JavaScript
description: A high-level, interpreted programming language that conforms to the ECMAScript specification. JavaScript has curly-bracket syntax, dynamic typing, prototype-based object-orientation, and first-class functions.

name: JavaScript Object Notation
description: An open standard file format and data interchange format that uses human-readable text to store and transmit data objects consisting of attribute?value pairs and arrays (or other serializable values).

name: Key Performance Indicator
description: A type of performance measurement. KPIs evaluate the success of an organization or of a particular activity in which it engages.

name: Local Area Network
description: A computer network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a residence, school, laboratory, university campus or office building.

name: Liquid Crystal Display
description: A flat-panel display or other electronically modulated optical device that uses the light-modulating properties of liquid crystals combined with polarizers.

name: Light Emitting Diode
description: A semiconductor light source that emits light when current flows through it. Electrons in the semiconductor recombine with electron holes, releasing energy in the form of photons.

name: Lithium-ion
description: A type of rechargeable battery. Lithium-ion batteries are commonly used for portable electronics and electric vehicles and are growing in popularity for military and aerospace applications.

name: Laughing Out Loud
description: A popular element of Internet slang, used to denote great amusement in chat and online conversation.

name: Long-Term Evolution
description: A standard for wireless broadband communication for mobile devices and data terminals, based on the GSM/EDGE and UMTS/HSPA technologies.

name: Machine Learning
description: A field of computer science that uses statistical techniques to give computer systems the ability to 'learn' from data, without being explicitly programmed.

name: Multimedia Messaging Service
description: A standard way to send messages that include multimedia content to and from a mobile phone over a cellular network.

name: MPEG Audio Layer-3
description: A coding format for digital audio which uses a form of lossy data compression. It is a common audio format for consumer audio streaming or storage, as well as a de facto standard of digital audio compression for the transfer and playback of music on most digital audio players.

name: MPEG-4 Part 14
description: A digital multimedia container format most commonly used to store video and audio, but it can also be used to store other data such as subtitles and still images.

name: Moving Picture Experts Group
description: An organization that develops standards for digital video and audio compression. It operates under the auspices of the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). The term also refers to the family of digital video compression standards and file formats developed by the group.

name: Mobile Switching Center
description: A component of 2G and 3G cellular networks that approves or rejects voice communications from one device to another and helps manage roaming. It uses the Home Location Register (HLR) or a Visitor Location Register (VLR) and the device?s SIM to authenticate the subscriber, determine whether they have permission to access the network, and ensure that the subscriber gets charged properly for any services they use.

name: National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics
description: A U.S. federal agency founded to undertake, promote, and institutionalize aeronautical research. It was dissolved in 1958 and its assets and personnel were transferred to NASA.

name: North American Free Trade Agreement
description: An agreement signed by Canada, Mexico, and the United States, creating a trilateral trade bloc in North America.

name: National Aeronautics and Space Administration
description: An independent agency of the U.S. federal government responsible for the civilian space program, as well as aeronautics and space research.

name: North Atlantic Treaty Organization
description: An intergovernmental military alliance between 30 European and North American countries.

name: Near Field Communication
description: A set of communication protocols for communication between two electronic devices over a distance of 4 cm (1 1/2 in) or less.

name: Natural Language Processing
description: A subfield of linguistics, computer science, and artificial intelligence concerned with the interactions between computers and human language.

name: Not Only SQL
description: A type of database that provides a mechanism for storage and retrieval of data that is modeled in means other than the tabular relations used in relational databases.

name: National Security Agency
description: A national-level intelligence agency of the United States Department of Defense, under the authority of the Director of National Intelligence.

name: Organic Light Emitting Diode
description: A light-emitting diode (LED) in which the emissive electroluminescent layer is a film of organic compound that emits light in response to an electric current.

name: Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries
description: An intergovernmental organization of 13 nations. Founded on 14 September 1960 in Baghdad by the first five members (Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Saudi Arabia, and Venezuela), and headquartered since 1965 in Vienna, Austria.

name: Operating System
description: Software that manages computer hardware, software resources, and provides various services for computer programs.

name: Occupational Safety and Health Administration
description: An agency of the United States Department of Labor. Its mission is to ensure safe and healthful working conditions for working men and women by setting and enforcing standards and by providing training, outreach, education and assistance.

name: Price to Earnings Ratio
description: A valuation ratio of a company's current share price compared to its per-share earnings.

name: Peer-to-Peer
description: A distributed application architecture that partitions tasks or workloads between peers.

name: Platform as a Service
description: A category of cloud computing services that provides a platform allowing customers to develop, run, and manage applications without the complexity of building and maintaining the infrastructure typically associated with developing and launching an app.

name: Portable Document Format
description: A file format developed by Adobe in 1993 to present documents, including text formatting and images, in a manner independent of application software, hardware, and operating systems.

name: Portable Network Graphics
description: A raster-graphics file-format that supports lossless data compression.

name: Property, Plant, and Equipment
description: A company's physical or fixed assets that include land, buildings, and machinery.

name: Pay Per Click
description: An internet advertising model used to drive traffic to websites, in which an advertiser pays a publisher when the ad is clicked.

name: Public Relations
description: The practice of deliberately managing the release and spread of information between an individual or an organization and the public.

name: Postscript
description: A comment, note, or thought added after the letter is finished and signed.

name: Questions and Answers
description: A process or instance of questioning and answering.

name: Quantum Dot Light Emitting Diode
description: A technology that uses quantum dots to enhance the performance in key picture quality areas.

name: Research and Development
description: Work directed towards the innovation, introduction, and improvement of products and processes.

name: Random Access Memory
description: A type of computer memory that can be accessed randomly.

name: Radio Frequency Identification
description: The use of radio waves to read and capture information stored on a tag attached to an object.

name: Request For Proposal
description: A business document that announces and provides details about a project.

name: Ribonucleic Acid
description: A nucleic acid present in all living cells. Its principal role is to act as a messenger carrying instructions from DNA.

name: Return on Assets
description: An indicator of how profitable a company is relative to its total assets.

name: Return on Ad Spend
description: A marketing metric that measures the efficacy of a digital advertising campaign.

name: Return on Equity
description: The amount of net income returned as a percentage of shareholders equity.

name: Return on Investment
description: A performance measure used to evaluate the efficiency of an investment.

name: Revolutions Per Minute
description: A measure of the frequency of rotation, specifically the number of rotations around a fixed axis in one minute.

name: Really Simple Syndication
description: A type of web feed which allows users to access updates to online content in a standardized, computer-readable format.

name: R?pondez S'il Vous Pla?t
description: A request for a response from the invited person or people.

name: Read The Fucking Manual
description: A phrase expressing frustration at someone's ignorance or ineptitude, often in tech or computing contexts.

name: Software as a Service
description: A software licensing and delivery model in which software is licensed on a subscription basis and is centrally hosted.

name: Securities and Exchange Commission
description: A large independent agency of the United States federal government that was created following the stock market crash in the 1920s to protect investors and the national banking system.

name: Search Engine Marketing
description: A form of Internet marketing that involves the promotion of websites by increasing their visibility in search engine results pages primarily through paid advertising.

name: Search Engine Optimization
description: The process of maximizing the number of visitors to a particular website by ensuring that the site appears high on the list of results returned by a search engine.

name: Subscriber Identity Module
description: An integrated circuit that is intended to securely store the international mobile subscriber identity (IMSI) number and its related key, which are used to identify and authenticate subscribers on mobile telephony devices.

name: Social Media Marketing
description: The use of social media platforms and websites to promote a product or service.

name: Short Message Service
description: A text messaging service component of most telephone, Internet, and mobile device systems.

name: Structured Query Language
description: A standard language for managing and manipulating databases.

name: Solid State Drive
description: A type of mass storage device similar to a hard disk drive (HDD). It supports reading and writing data and maintains stored data in a permanent state even without power.

name: Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics
description: A term used to group together these academic disciplines. This term is typically used when addressing education policy and curriculum choices in schools to improve competitiveness in science and technology development.

name: Scalable Vector Graphics
description: An XML-based vector image format for two-dimensional graphics with support for interactivity and animation.

name: To Be Announced
description: A placeholder for information that is intended to be filled in once it becomes available.

name: To Be Determined
description: A placeholder for information that is intended to be filled in once a decision has been made.

name: Transmission Control Protocol
description: One of the main protocols in the Internet protocol suite. It originated in the initial network implementation in which it complemented the Internet Protocol (IP).

name: Time Division Multiple Access
description: A channel access method for shared medium networks. It allows several users to share the same frequency channel by dividing the signal into different time slots.

name: Temporary Mobile Subscriber Identity
description: A temporary identifier that is used in the mobile network. It is randomly generated and sent by the network to the mobile device. It is used instead of the IMSI to maintain user privacy on the air interface and to minimize the number of times that the IMSI is transmitted.

name: United Arab Emirates
description: A country in Western Asia at the northeast end of the Arabian Peninsula on the Persian Gulf, bordering Oman to the east and Saudi Arabia to the south and west, as well as sharing maritime borders with Qatar to the west and Iran to the north.

name: User Datagram Protocol
description: One of the core members of the Internet protocol suite. The protocol was designed by David P. Reed in 1980 and formally defined in RFC 768.

name: User Interface
description: The space where interactions between humans and machines occur. The goal of this interaction is to allow effective operation and control of the machine from the human end, while the machine simultaneously feeds back information that aids the operators' decision-making process.

name: United Kingdom
description: A sovereign country located off the north-western coast of the European mainland. The United Kingdom includes the island of Great Britain, the north-eastern part of the island of Ireland, and many smaller islands.

name: United Nations
description: An international organization formed in 1945 to increase political and economic cooperation among its member countries. It works on economic and social development programs, improving human rights and reducing global conflicts.

name: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
description: A specialized agency of the United Nations aimed at promoting world peace and security through international cooperation in education, the sciences, and culture.

name: United Parcel Service
description: An American multinational package delivery and supply chain management company.

name: Uniform Resource Locator
description: The address of a resource on the Internet. A URL indicates the location of a resource as well as the protocol used to access it.

name: United States of America
description: A country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation?s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

name: Universal Serial Bus
description: An industry standard that establishes specifications for cables, connectors and protocols for connection, communication and power supply between personal computers and their peripheral devices.

name: United States Postal Service
description: An independent agency of the executive branch of the United States federal government responsible for providing postal service in the United States.

name: Union of Soviet Socialist Republics
description: A federal socialist state in Northern Eurasia that existed from 1922 to 1991. It was a state where the whole economy was planned, directed and controlled by the government.

name: User Experience
description: A person's emotions and attitudes about using a particular product, system or service. It includes the practical, experiential, affective, meaningful and valuable aspects of human-computer interaction and product ownership.

name: Video Graphics Array
description: A graphics standard for video display controller first introduced with the IBM PS/2 line of computers in 1987.

name: Very Important Person
description: A person who is accorded special privileges due to their status or importance.

name: Visitor Location Register
description: A database of the subscribers who have roamed into the jurisdiction of the Mobile Switching Center (MSC) which it serves. Each base station in the network is served by exactly one VLR, hence a subscriber cannot be present in more than one VLR at a time.

name: Voice over IP
description: A methodology and group of technologies for the delivery of voice communications and multimedia sessions over Internet Protocol (IP) networks, such as the Internet.

name: Virtual Private Network
description: A virtual network built on top of existing physical networks that can provide a secure communication mechanism for data and other information transmitted between networks.

name: Virtual Reality
description: A simulated experience that can be similar to or completely different from the real world.

name: Versus
description: A term used to denote a contest or comparison, like in a sporting event or legal case.

name: Wide Area Network
description: A telecommunications network that extends over a largegeographical area for the purpose of computer networking. Wide area networks are often established with leased telecommunication circuits.

name: World Economic Forum
description: An international organization for public-private cooperation. The Forum engages the foremost political, business, cultural and other leaders of society to shape global, regional and industry agendas. It is independent, impartial and not tied to any special interests. The Forum strives in all its efforts to demonstrate entrepreneurship in the global public interest while upholding the highest standards of governance.

name: World Health Organization
description: A specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health.

name: Wi-Fi
description: A family of wireless network protocols, based on the IEEE 802.11 family of standards, which are commonly used for local area networking of devices and Internet access.

name: World Trade Organization
description: An intergovernmental organization that is concerned with the regulation of international trade between nations.

name: eXtensible Markup Language
description: A markup language that defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.

name: Exclusive OR
description: A logical operation that outputs true only when inputs differ (one is true, the other is false). It is symbolized by the prefix operator J and by the infix operators XOR, EOR, EXOR, ⊻, ⩒, ⩛, ⊕, ↮, and ≢.

name: Year 2000
description: A problem for both digital (computer-related) and non-digital documentation and data storage situations which resulted from the practice of abbreviating a four-digit year to two digits.

name: Your Mileage May Vary
description: A disclaimer stating that one's opinion is a subjective measure, rather than an objective fact, and thus that different people may reach different conclusions despite having the same evidence.

name: Zettabyte File System
description: A combined file system and logical volume manager designed by Sun Microsystems. The features of ZFS include protection against data corruption, support for high storage capacities, efficient data compression, integration of the concepts of filesystem and volume management, snapshots and copy-on-write clones, continuous integrity checking and automatic repair, RAID-Z and native NFSv4 ACLs.

name: Zipping
description: A file format and a software application used for compressing and archiving files. It was created in 1989 by Phil Katz.

name: ZooKeeper
description: A centralized service for maintaining configuration information, naming, providing distributed synchronization, and providing group services.
